elements.content: Post-neurosurgical meningitis (PNM) often leads to serious consequences; unfortunately, the commonly used clinical diagnostic methods of PNM are time-consuming or have low specificity. To realize the accurate and convenient diagnosis of PNM, herein, we propose a comprehensive strategy for cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis based on a machine-learning-aided cross-reactive sensing array. The sensing array involves three Eu3+-doped metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), which can generate specific fluorescence responding patterns after reacting with potential targets in CSF. Then, the responding pattern is used as learning data to train the machine learning algorithms. The discrimination confidence for artificial CSF containing different components of molecules, proteins, and cells is from 81.3 to 100%. Furthermore, the machine-learning-aided sensing array was applied in the analysis of CSF samples from post-neurosurgical patients. Only 25 μL of CSF samples was needed, and the samples could be robustly classified into “normal,” “mild,” or “severe” groups within 40 min. It is believed that the combination of machine learning algorithms with robust data processing capability and a lanthanide luminescent sensor array will provide a reliable alternative for more comprehensive, convenient, and rapid diagnosis of PNM.
elements.clean_text: Post-neurosurgical meningitis (PNM) often leads to serious consequences; unfortunately, the commonly used clinical diagnostic methods of PNM are time-consuming or have low specificity. To realize the accurate and convenient diagnosis of PNM, herein, we propose a comprehensive strategy for cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis based on a machine-learning-aided cross-reactive sensing array. The sensing array involves three Eu3+-doped metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), which can generate specific fluorescence responding patterns after reacting with potential targets in CSF. Then, the responding pattern is used as learning data to train the machine learning algorithms. The discrimination confidence for artificial CSF containing different components of molecules, proteins, and cells is from 81.3 to 100%. Furthermore, the machine-learning-aided sensing array was applied in the analysis of CSF samples from post-neurosurgical patients. Only 25 μL of CSF samples was needed, and the samples could be robustly classified into "normal," "mild," or "severe" groups within 40 min. It is believed that the combination of machine learning algorithms with robust data processing capability and a lanthanide luminescent sensor array will provide a reliable alternative for more comprehensive, convenient, and rapid diagnosis of PNM.

elements.content: Postoperative infection is a serious issue that cannot be ignored as it always slows wound healing and, in severe cases, affects the prognosis of the surgical operation. Among the postoperative infections, the most serious and life-threatening is post-neurosurgical meningitis (PNM). Although great progress has been acquired in brain surgery technology, the emergence of PNM is inevitable. The worldwide incidence rate of PNM is varied with many factors and can be more than 8% in some reports. The diagnosis of PNM is more difficult than community-acquired meningitis because neurosurgical patients often undergo febrile neurological compromise and consciousness decrease, which mask the presentation of meningitis. A lumbar puncture and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) examination are necessary for early identification of PNM.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Postoperative infection is a serious issue that cannot be ignored as it always slows wound healing and, in severe cases, affects the prognosis of the surgical operation. Among the postoperative infections, the most serious and life-threatening is post-neurosurgical meningitis (PNM). Although great progress has been acquired in brain surgery technology, the emergence of PNM is inevitable. The worldwide incidence rate of PNM is varied with many factors and can be more than 8% in some reports. The diagnosis of PNM is more difficult than community-acquired meningitis because neurosurgical patients often undergo febrile neurological compromise and consciousness decrease, which mask the presentation of meningitis. A lumbar puncture and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) examination are necessary for early identification of PNM.

elements.content: At present, the clinical diagnosis of PNM is mainly determined by microbiological examination and the laboratory values of CSF. For microbiological examination of CSF, a false negative signal always appears even with serious PNM patients. As for the laboratory values of CSF, the total protein levels and the counts of leukocyte and red cells are provided. Although the leukocyte count of CSF is the most relevant to the pathogenesis of PNM, it is not a specific biomarker because some other diseases, like cerebral hemorrhage, may also induce the increase of CSF leukocyte count.
elements.clean_text: At present, the clinical diagnosis of PNM is mainly determined by microbiological examination and the laboratory values of CSF. For microbiological examination of CSF, a false negative signal always appears even with serious PNM patients. As for the laboratory values of CSF, the total protein levels and the counts of leukocyte and red cells are provided. Although the leukocyte count of CSF is the most relevant to the pathogenesis of PNM, it is not a specific biomarker because some other diseases, like cerebral hemorrhage, may also induce the increase of CSF leukocyte count.

elements.content: Many clinical studies reported the potential of molecules and proteins in the diagnosis of PNM. For example, the concentration of CSF lactate was most closely related to PNM. A threshold of 4 mM CSF lactate has been widely used as a cutoff point in identifying PNM. The ratio of CSF/blood glucose has also been reported to be of high relevance in PNM. In addition, Maskin et al.’s work discovered that the concentration of CSF protein is related to PNM. Considering the complexity of PNM diagnosis, we anticipate to construct a method that can comprehensively reflect the changes of CSF based on multiple kinds of detection targets.
elements.clean_text: Many clinical studies reported the potential of molecules and proteins in the diagnosis of PNM. For example, the concentration of CSF lactate was most closely related to PNM. A threshold of 4 mM CSF lactate has been widely used as a cutoff point in identifying PNM. The ratio of CSF/blood glucose has also been reported to be of high relevance in PNM. In addition, Maskin et al.'s work discovered that the concentration of CSF protein is related to PNM. Considering the complexity of PNM diagnosis, we anticipate to construct a method that can comprehensively reflect the changes of CSF based on multiple kinds of detection targets.

elements.content: Cross-reactive sensing arrays can generate specific patterns from different targets, which are subsequently classified to generate algorithms for identifying targets. Benefiting from their robust pattern-based sensing, sensing arrays have been successfully applied in the assay of exhalation, serum, and tissues. However, pattern-based CSF sensing has never been reported. Data processing is significant to acquire accurate assay results of sensing arrays; machine learning (ML)-based artificial intelligence has served as an efficient and reliable tool for processing large amounts of data. ML algorithms such as k-nearest neighbors (k-NNs) and artificial neural networks (ANNs) are able to learn from a part of data and focus on the prediction of other data. Therefore, it is anticipated that the combination of a sensing array with ML algorithms is able to comprehensively identify the biomarkers consisting of molecules, proteins, cells, and even some unknown biomarkers.
elements.clean_text: Cross-reactive sensing arrays can generate specific patterns from different targets, which are subsequently classified to generate algorithms for identifying targets. Benefiting from their robust pattern-based sensing, sensing arrays have been successfully applied in the assay of exhalation, serum, and tissues. However, pattern-based CSF sensing has never been reported. Data processing is significant to acquire accurate assay results of sensing arrays; machine learning (ML)-based artificial intelligence has served as an efficient and reliable tool for processing large amounts of data. ML algorithms such as k-nearest neighbors (k-NNs) and artificial neural networks (ANNs) are able to learn from a part of data and focus on the prediction of other data. Therefore, it is anticipated that the combination of a sensing array with ML algorithms is able to comprehensively identify the biomarkers consisting of molecules, proteins, cells, and even some unknown biomarkers.

elements.content: Accordingly, we report an ML-assisted sensing array consisting of three Eu3+-doped metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), which can realize the diagnosis of PNM from 25 μL of CSF samples within 40 min (). The Eu3+-doped MOFs (EMs) are selected because of their binary merits of functional diversity and structural adjustability for MOFs and the high resolution and low background signal of lanthanide luminescence. After the sensing array was reacted with targets, the fluorescence change was processed by k-NN and ANN algorithms and good discrimination and determination of different potential targets in the complex CSF can be acquired. Finally, the sensing array was reacted with the CSF from post-neurosurgical patients and successfully distinguished normal individuals from mild and severe PNM patients, with an accuracy of 86.7%. What is exciting is that the sensing array can be applied to the individualized monitoring of the treatment process of PNM patients, providing an effective and objective evaluation of the clinical treatment effect.
elements.clean_text: Accordingly, we report an ML-assisted sensing array consisting of three Eu3+-doped metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), which can realize the diagnosis of PNM from 25 μL of CSF samples within 40 min (). The Eu3+-doped MOFs (EMs) are selected because of their binary merits of functional diversity and structural adjustability for MOFs and the high resolution and low background signal of lanthanide luminescence. After the sensing array was reacted with targets, the fluorescence change was processed by k-NN and ANN algorithms and good discrimination and determination of different potential targets in the complex CSF can be acquired. Finally, the sensing array was reacted with the CSF from post-neurosurgical patients and successfully distinguished normal individuals from mild and severe PNM patients, with an accuracy of 86.7%. What is exciting is that the sensing array can be applied to the individualized monitoring of the treatment process of PNM patients, providing an effective and objective evaluation of the clinical treatment effect.

elements.clean_text: 1  Schematic Illustration of PNM Diagnosis Based on the Comprehensive Analysis of Cerebrospinal Fluid by the Machine-Learning-Aided Sensing Array of Eu3+-Doped Metal-Organic Frameworks

elements.content: The k-nearest neighbor (k-NN) algorithm was constructed by Python v 3.9.0; 75% of the data points were extracted to train the k-NN algorithm and generate a training set, and the other 25% of the data points generated a test set. After choosing an appropriate value of k, k training samples were chosen to predict the information of a test sample. The accuracy of confusion matrices was accessed through the comparison between predicted outputs and real data.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Construction of the Machine Learning Algorithm

The k-nearest neighbor (k-NN) algorithm was constructed by Python v 3.9.0; 75% of the data points were extracted to train the k-NN algorithm and generate a training set, and the other 25% of the data points generated a test set. After choosing an appropriate value of k, k training samples were chosen to predict the information of a test sample. The accuracy of confusion matrices was accessed through the comparison between predicted outputs and real data.

elements.content: The artificial neural network (ANN) algorithm was constructed by MATLAB 2014a, and it was a two-layer feed-forward network with sigmoid hidden neurons and softmax output neurons. The network was trained with scaled conjugate gradient backpropagation, and its performance was evaluated by cross-entropy and confusion matrices. The same data in each group was randomly divided into training (70%), validation (15%), and testing (15%) sets. The training sets were presented to the network during training, and the network was adjusted according to its error. The validation sets were used to measure network generalization and to halt training when generalization stopped improving.
elements.clean_text: The artificial neural network (ANN) algorithm was constructed by MATLAB 2014a, and it was a two-layer feed-forward network with sigmoid hidden neurons and softmax output neurons. The network was trained with scaled conjugate gradient backpropagation, and its performance was evaluated by cross-entropy and confusion matrices. The same data in each group was randomly divided into training (70%), validation (15%), and testing (15%) sets. The training sets were presented to the network during training, and the network was adjusted according to its error. The validation sets were used to measure network generalization and to halt training when generalization stopped improving.

elements.content:
First, 50 μL of the EM1, EM2, and EM3 solutions (2 mg·mL–1) was mixed with artificial cerebrospinal fluid separately.

Then, for the identification of molecules, different small molecules (DA, LA, H2O2, GSH, Glu, H2S, and AA) were added, and the final volume was kept at 500 μL. Among them, Na2S was substituted for H2S as it is easier to access and store. For the identification of proteins, different proteins (CAT, HSA, LDH, Lyso, TRF, and SOD) with various concentrations (50, 100, 200, 300, and 400 μg·mL–1) were added, and the final volume was kept at 500 μL. For the identification of cells, different cell lines (BV-2, Thp-1, and RAW264.7) were added, and the final volume was kept at 500 μL.
elements.clean_text:
Identification of Molecules, Proteins, and Cells by the Sensor Array

First, 50 μL of the EM1, EM2, and EM3 solutions (2 mg⋅mL-1) was mixed with artificial cerebrospinal fluid separately.

Then, for the identification of molecules, different small molecules (DA, LA, H2O2, GSH, Glu, H2S, and AA) were added, and the final volume was kept at 500 μL. Among them, Na2S was substituted for H2S as it is easier to access and store. For the identification of proteins, different proteins (CAT, HSA, LDH, Lyso, TRF, and SOD) with various concentrations (50, 100, 200, 300, and 400 μg⋅mL-1) were added, and the final volume was kept at 500 μL. For the identification of cells, different cell lines (BV-2, Thp-1, and RAW264.7) were added, and the final volume was kept at 500 μL.

elements.content: After 30 min of incubation at room temperature, the fluorescence spectra before (I 0) and after adding targets (I) of the mixture were recorded at Ex/Em (nm) 300:616 nm (scanning range: 520–750 nm). The difference between the two values (ΔI = I 0 – I) was used as the response signal for sensing analysis. This procedure was repeated to produce four replicates to obtain a data matrix of 3 MOFs × 7 molecules × 4 replicates, 3 MOFs × 6 proteins × 4 replicates, or 3 MOFs × 3 cells × 4 replicates. Finally, the obtained data were analyzed using linear discriminant analysis (LDA) in SPSS v 20.0, k-NN, and ANN.
elements.clean_text: After 30 min of incubation at room temperature, the fluorescence spectra before (I 0) and after adding targets (I) of the mixture were recorded at Ex/Em (nm) 300:616 nm (scanning range: 520-750 nm). The difference between the two values (ΔI = I 0 - I) was used as the response signal for sensing analysis. This procedure was repeated to produce four replicates to obtain a data matrix of 3 MOFs × 7 molecules × 4 replicates, 3 MOFs × 6 proteins × 4 replicates, or 3 MOFs × 3 cells × 4 replicates. Finally, the obtained data were analyzed using linear discriminant analysis (LDA) in SPSS v 20.0, k-NN, and ANN.

elements.content: Cerebrospinal fluid samples were obtained from the Nanfang Hospital of Southern Medical University. Informed consent was obtained in all cases, and the research was approved by the scientific ethical committee of Southern Medical University. To identify and diagnose the PNM, the lumbar puncture was implemented for neurosurgical patients; 25 μL of the cerebrospinal fluid sample was collected and mixed with 50 μL of three MOFs solution (2 mg·mL–1) and artificial cerebrospinal fluid, and the final volume was kept at 500 μL. After 30 min of incubation at room temperature, the fluorescence spectra before (I 0) and after adding different cerebrospinal fluid samples (I) of the mixture were recorded at Ex/Em (nm) 300:616 nm (scanning range: 520–750 nm). The difference between the two values (ΔI = I 0 – I) was used as the response signal for sensing analysis. Finally, the obtained data were analyzed using linear discriminant analysis (LDA) in SPSS v 20.0, k-NN, and ANN.
elements.clean_text:
Diagnosis of Meningitis by the Fluorescence Sensor Array

Cerebrospinal fluid samples were obtained from the Nanfang Hospital of Southern Medical University. Informed consent was obtained in all cases, and the research was approved by the scientific ethical committee of Southern Medical University. To identify and diagnose the PNM, the lumbar puncture was implemented for neurosurgical patients; 25 μL of the cerebrospinal fluid sample was collected and mixed with 50 μL of three MOFs solution (2 mg⋅mL-1) and artificial cerebrospinal fluid, and the final volume was kept at 500 μL. After 30 min of incubation at room temperature, the fluorescence spectra before (I 0) and after adding different cerebrospinal fluid samples (I) of the mixture were recorded at Ex/Em (nm) 300:616 nm (scanning range: 520-750 nm). The difference between the two values (ΔI = I 0 - I) was used as the response signal for sensing analysis. Finally, the obtained data were analyzed using linear discriminant analysis (LDA) in SPSS v 20.0, k-NN, and ANN.

elements.content: The sensing array is composed of three Eu3+-doped MOFs; they are Eu3+/UIO-66, Eu3+/HKUST-1, and Eu3+/MIL-53, denoted as EM1, EM2, and EM3. As shown in SEM images in , both EM1 and EM3 present a spherical structure, and the average sizes are 40 ± 5.62 and 200 ± 46 nm, respectively. EM2 shows an octahedral structure with an average size of 500 ± 50 nm. The PXRD patterns of the three EMs are consistent with their standard PXRD patterns, indicating that the doping of Eu3+ does not influence the crystal structure of MOFs (d–f). The FT-IR spectra correspond with their organic ligands (g) for EM1; the stretching vibrations of νas (−COO−) and νs (−COO−) at 1581 and 1396 cm–1 belong to the characteristic bands of the carboxylate group in ligands, and the peak of the benzene ring is at 1506 cm–1. As for EM2, the absorption band at 1630 cm–1 is attributed to the stretching vibration of −COOH groups; the peak at 1450 cm–1 is assigned to the stretching vibration of the −CC bond. For EM3, the peak at 600 cm–1 should correspond to Al–O stretching vibrations. Furthermore, the three Eu3+-doped MOFs reveal the main emission wavelength of Eu3+ (616 nm) upon excitation at 300 nm due to the sensitization of the organic ligand to Eu3+ (5D0–7F2), implying the successful introduction of Eu3+ (h). The ζ potentials of the three EMs are −24.5, −14.3, and −4.75 mV, respectively (i).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Characterization of EM1, EM2, and EM3

The sensing array is composed of three Eu3+-doped MOFs; they are Eu3+/UIO-66, Eu3+/HKUST-1, and Eu3+/MIL-53, denoted as EM1, EM2, and EM3. As shown in SEM images in , both EM1 and EM3 present a spherical structure, and the average sizes are 40 ± 5.62 and 200 ± 46 nm, respectively. EM2 shows an octahedral structure with an average size of 500 ± 50 nm. The PXRD patterns of the three EMs are consistent with their standard PXRD patterns, indicating that the doping of Eu3+ does not influence the crystal structure of MOFs (d-f). The FT-IR spectra correspond with their organic ligands (g) for EM1; the stretching vibrations of νas (-COO-) and νs (-COO-) at 1581 and 1396 cm-1 belong to the characteristic bands of the carboxylate group in ligands, and the peak of the benzene ring is at 1506 cm-1. As for EM2, the absorption band at 1630 cm-1 is attributed to the stretching vibration of -COOH groups; the peak at 1450 cm-1 is assigned to the stretching vibration of the -CC bond. For EM3, the peak at 600 cm-1 should correspond to Al-O stretching vibrations. Furthermore, the three Eu3+-doped MOFs reveal the main emission wavelength of Eu3+ (616 nm) upon excitation at 300 nm due to the sensitization of the organic ligand to Eu3+ (5D0-7F2), implying the successful introduction of Eu3+ (h). The ζ potentials of the three EMs are -24.5, -14.3, and -4.75 mV, respectively (i).

elements.content: SEM images and PXRD patterns of (a, d) EM1, (b, e) EM2, and (c, f) EM3. The FT-IR spectra (g), photoluminescence spectra (h), and ζ potentials (i) of the three Eu3+-doped MOFs. The insets of panel (h) are the photographs of three MOFs Eu3+-doped under 265 nm UV light.
elements.clean_text: 1  SEM images and PXRD patterns of (a, d) EM1, (b, e) EM2, and (c, f) EM3. The FT-IR spectra (g), photoluminescence spectra (h), and ζ potentials (i) of the three Eu3+-doped MOFs. The insets of panel (h) are the photographs of three MOFs Eu3+-doped under 265 nm UV light.

elements.content: Seven molecules are utilized to test the identification and determination ability of potential PNM molecular markers in CSF. Lactate (LA), glucose (Glu), and hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) are inflammation-related molecules; ascorbic acid (AA), glutathione (GSH), and hydrogen sulfide (H2S) are critical in neuroprotection and neuromodulation; and dopamine (DA) is a typical neurotransmitter. The response of each sensor toward 100 μM molecules is first studied in Figures S1 and a, in which I 0 and I represent the fluorescence intensity at 616 nm of the sensor before and after the reaction with molecules, respectively. The potential mechanism of the molecule-induced optical change is examined, and the results are shown in Figure S2. The luminescence change of EM2 is not obvious, mainly because Cu2+ in HKUST-1 can quench the lanthanide luminescence. There is no overlap for the absorption of molecules with the corresponding wavelengths (Figure S2a) with the excitation/emission wavelength of 300:616 nm; thus, no inner filter effect occurs between molecules and the three EMs. After the reaction with H2O2, the crystal structure of EM1 is disrupted (Figure S2b), which may lead to the luminescence quenching of EM1, while the crystal structure of EM3 is stable (Figure S2c). It can be seen from Figures S2d–f that the lifetime of Eu3+ emission in EM1 and EM3 decrease in the presence of DA, indicating nonradiative energy transfer from the Eu3+ ion to the DA molecule. In addition, 100 μM DA was separately reacted with three EMs, then the mixtures were centrifugated, and the UV–vis absorption spectra of the supernatant were measured. The result in Figure S2g reveals that an abundance of DA can coordinate with EM1, which may also contribute to the highest response of EM1. The lifetime of three EMs after reacting with GSH, LA, Glu, and AA, respectively, is detected. As shown in Figures S2h–k, the four molecules can all prolong the lifetime of lanthanide luminescence more or less, implying an enhanced antenna effect toward Eu3+-doped MOFs. The different levels of emission enhancement are also estimated to have resulted from the various surface areas and charges of three EMs. The H2S can react with Cu2+ in EM2 to induce the structural collapse of EM2 (Figure S2l), which disrupts the quenching by Cu2+ and increases luminescence of EM2.
elements.clean_text:
Identification and Determination of CSF Molecules

Seven molecules are utilized to test the identification and determination ability of potential PNM molecular markers in CSF. Lactate (LA), glucose (Glu), and hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) are inflammation-related molecules; ascorbic acid (AA), glutathione (GSH), and hydrogen sulfide (H2S) are critical in neuroprotection and neuromodulation; and dopamine (DA) is a typical neurotransmitter. The response of each sensor toward 100 μM molecules is first studied in Figures S1 and a, in which I 0 and I represent the fluorescence intensity at 616 nm of the sensor before and after the reaction with molecules, respectively. The potential mechanism of the molecule-induced optical change is examined, and the results are shown in Figure S2. The luminescence change of EM2 is not obvious, mainly because Cu2+ in HKUST-1 can quench the lanthanide luminescence. There is no overlap for the absorption of molecules with the corresponding wavelengths (Figure S2a) with the excitation/emission wavelength of 300:616 nm; thus, no inner filter effect occurs between molecules and the three EMs. After the reaction with H2O2, the crystal structure of EM1 is disrupted (Figure S2b), which may lead to the luminescence quenching of EM1, while the crystal structure of EM3 is stable (Figure S2c). It can be seen from Figures S2d-f that the lifetime of Eu3+ emission in EM1 and EM3 decrease in the presence of DA, indicating nonradiative energy transfer from the Eu3+ ion to the DA molecule. In addition, 100 μM DA was separately reacted with three EMs, then the mixtures were centrifugated, and the UV-vis absorption spectra of the supernatant were measured. The result in Figure S2g reveals that an abundance of DA can coordinate with EM1, which may also contribute to the highest response of EM1. The lifetime of three EMs after reacting with GSH, LA, Glu, and AA, respectively, is detected. As shown in Figures S2h-k, the four molecules can all prolong the lifetime of lanthanide luminescence more or less, implying an enhanced antenna effect toward Eu3+-doped MOFs. The different levels of emission enhancement are also estimated to have resulted from the various surface areas and charges of three EMs. The H2S can react with Cu2+ in EM2 to induce the structural collapse of EM2 (Figure S2l), which disrupts the quenching by Cu2+ and increases luminescence of EM2.

elements.content: (a) Fluorescence response (I 0 – I) patterns of the sensor array against various molecules (100 μM). (b) LDA plots for the sensor array against seven small molecules. (c) Confusion matrix of the discrimination of seven molecules based on the data of sensor array. LDA plots for the sensor array against lactate (LA) at different concentrations without (d) and with (e) interferences. (f) LDA plots for the sensor array against different proportions of lactate and glucose in artificial cerebrospinal fluid.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Fluorescence response (I 0 - I) patterns of the sensor array against various molecules (100 μM). (b) LDA plots for the sensor array against seven small molecules. (c) Confusion matrix of the discrimination of seven molecules based on the data of sensor array. LDA plots for the sensor array against lactate (LA) at different concentrations without (d) and with (e) interferences. (f) LDA plots for the sensor array against different proportions of lactate and glucose in artificial cerebrospinal fluid.

elements.content: In the preliminary study, linear discriminant analysis (LDA) was utilized to investigate the fluorescence change, and the most significant two factors (factor 1 = 90.4% and factor 2 = 9.1%) were used to generate a two-dimensional (2D) plot. b reveals that seven molecules can be clearly separated from each other at 100 μM. Furthermore, the k-nearest neighbor (k-NN) algorithms are utilized to examine the discriminant accuracy, and the results are shown in c. The rows and columns in the confusion matrix are true classes and predicted classes, respectively. Most of the molecules can be discriminated perfectly, except that 29% of DA, 22% of Glu, and 57% of H2S are false classifications; the discrimination confidence is 91.5%.
elements.clean_text: In the preliminary study, linear discriminant analysis (LDA) was utilized to investigate the fluorescence change, and the most significant two factors (factor 1 = 90.4% and factor 2 = 9.1%) were used to generate a two-dimensional (2D) plot. b reveals that seven molecules can be clearly separated from each other at 100 μM. Furthermore, the k-nearest neighbor (k-NN) algorithms are utilized to examine the discriminant accuracy, and the results are shown in c. The rows and columns in the confusion matrix are true classes and predicted classes, respectively. Most of the molecules can be discriminated perfectly, except that 29% of DA, 22% of Glu, and 57% of H2S are false classifications; the discrimination confidence is 91.5%.

elements.content: Apart from the qualitative analysis, the discrimination of different concentrations of molecules is also significant for a potential clinical diagnosis approach. An artificial cerebrospinal fluid was prepared to test the assay performance of the sensor array in the presence of interferents; the detailed composition of the artificial CSF is provided in Experiments of the Supporting Information. Lactate and glucose from 0.1 to 5 mM are reacted with the sensing array, and the optical response is analyzed by LDA. The results indicate that various concentrations of lactate (d,e and S3) or glucose (Figure S4) can be completely distinguished, either alone or in artificial cerebrospinal fluid. In addition, artificial cerebrospinal fluids containing different proportions of lactate and glucose are prepared to simulate more complex composition changes. f and S5 reveal that the artificial cerebrospinal fluid with different proportions of lactate and glucose (from 0.1mM Glu/4 mM LA to 0.5 mM LA/5 mM Glu) can also be discriminated after a reaction with the sensor array. The above results reveal that the proposed Eu3+-doped MOF array has a good performance for the identification and determination of CSF molecules.
elements.clean_text: Apart from the qualitative analysis, the discrimination of different concentrations of molecules is also significant for a potential clinical diagnosis approach. An artificial cerebrospinal fluid was prepared to test the assay performance of the sensor array in the presence of interferents; the detailed composition of the artificial CSF is provided in Experiments of the Supporting Information. Lactate and glucose from 0.1 to 5 mM are reacted with the sensing array, and the optical response is analyzed by LDA. The results indicate that various concentrations of lactate (d,e and S3) or glucose (Figure S4) can be completely distinguished, either alone or in artificial cerebrospinal fluid. In addition, artificial cerebrospinal fluids containing different proportions of lactate and glucose are prepared to simulate more complex composition changes. f and S5 reveal that the artificial cerebrospinal fluid with different proportions of lactate and glucose (from 0.1mM Glu/4 mM LA to 0.5 mM LA/5 mM Glu) can also be discriminated after a reaction with the sensor array. The above results reveal that the proposed Eu3+-doped MOF array has a good performance for the identification and determination of CSF molecules.

elements.content: Six kinds of proteins were selected as the model targets, among which transferrin (TRF), superoxide dismutase (SOD), lactic dehydrogenase (LDH), and catalyze (CAT) have been reported to be associated with inflammation. As shown in a, each protein (200 μg·mL–1) has its own pattern of luminescence response to three MOFs. The fluorescence intensity of EM1 is increased for almost all proteins, and the fluorescence intensity of EM2 and EM3 is slightly decreased.
elements.clean_text:
Identification and Determination of CSF Proteins

Six kinds of proteins were selected as the model targets, among which transferrin (TRF), superoxide dismutase (SOD), lactic dehydrogenase (LDH), and catalyze (CAT) have been reported to be associated with inflammation. As shown in a, each protein (200 μg⋅mL-1) has its own pattern of luminescence response to three MOFs. The fluorescence intensity of EM1 is increased for almost all proteins, and the fluorescence intensity of EM2 and EM3 is slightly decreased.

elements.content: Photoluminescence (I 0 – I) patterns of the sensor array for (a) various proteins (200 μg·mL–1), (d) different concentrations of HSA, and (g) the mixtures of different proportions of HSA and LDH under interferences. LDA plots for the sensor array against (b) various proteins, (e) different concentrations of HSA, and (h) the mixtures of different proportions of HSA and LDH under interferences. Confusion matrix of the discrimination of (c) various proteins, (f) different concentrations of HSA, and (i) the mixtures of different proportions of HSA and LDH under interferences based on the data of the entire sensor array.
elements.clean_text: 3  Photoluminescence (I 0 - I) patterns of the sensor array for (a) various proteins (200 μg⋅mL-1), (d) different concentrations of HSA, and (g) the mixtures of different proportions of HSA and LDH under interferences. LDA plots for the sensor array against (b) various proteins, (e) different concentrations of HSA, and (h) the mixtures of different proportions of HSA and LDH under interferences. Confusion matrix of the discrimination of (c) various proteins, (f) different concentrations of HSA, and (i) the mixtures of different proportions of HSA and LDH under interferences based on the data of the entire sensor array.

elements.content: The mechanism for the optical change of three EMs to proteins is studied. There is no overlap for the absorption of six proteins with the excitation/emission wavelength of 300:616 nm for EMs (Figure S6a). So, no inner filter effect occurs between proteins and the three EMs. The lifetime of the three EMs hardly changes with the existence of protein (Figures S6b–d). Furthermore, a molecular docking simulation is performed to verify and explore the interaction force between the ligands (H2BDC, H3BTC) of EMs and proteins (taking HSA as an example). Figure S6e demonstrates that there are mainly hydrogen bond interactions between H2BDC and amino acid residues of LYS-467, ARG-194, ASP-394, ARG-259, GLN-333, and TYR-359 of HSA. Figure S6f demonstrates the similar hydrogen bond interactions between H3BTC and amino acid residues of HSA. In addition, the six proteins with different isoelectric points (pI) have various surface charges (Table S1), which also affect the reaction of proteins with Eu3+-doped MOFs.
elements.clean_text: The mechanism for the optical change of three EMs to proteins is studied. There is no overlap for the absorption of six proteins with the excitation/emission wavelength of 300:616 nm for EMs (Figure S6a). So, no inner filter effect occurs between proteins and the three EMs. The lifetime of the three EMs hardly changes with the existence of protein (Figures S6b-d). Furthermore, a molecular docking simulation is performed to verify and explore the interaction force between the ligands (H2BDC, H3BTC) of EMs and proteins (taking HSA as an example). Figure S6e demonstrates that there are mainly hydrogen bond interactions between H2BDC and amino acid residues of LYS-467, ARG-194, ASP-394, ARG-259, GLN-333, and TYR-359 of HSA. Figure S6f demonstrates the similar hydrogen bond interactions between H3BTC and amino acid residues of HSA. In addition, the six proteins with different isoelectric points (pI) have various surface charges (Table S1), which also affect the reaction of proteins with Eu3+-doped MOFs.

elements.content: After the responding pattern was preliminarily analyzed by LDA, the most significant two factors (factor 1 = 83.3% and factor 2 = 15.2%) were used to generate a 2D plot, in which the response patterns are clustered into six groups with no overlap (b). The k-NN algorithm also reveals that the different proteins can be completely discriminated with a confidence of 100% (c). Compared to using only one EM or two EMs, it is observed that the correct classification rate of 100% can be achieved only when all three EMs are employed (Table S2). After that, the identification potential of unknown protein samples was explored. As shown in Table S3, the sensor array has demonstrated a 100% identification level, indicating the excellent discrimination ability of the sensor array.
elements.clean_text: After the responding pattern was preliminarily analyzed by LDA, the most significant two factors (factor 1 = 83.3% and factor 2 = 15.2%) were used to generate a 2D plot, in which the response patterns are clustered into six groups with no overlap (b). The k-NN algorithm also reveals that the different proteins can be completely discriminated with a confidence of 100% (c). Compared to using only one EM or two EMs, it is observed that the correct classification rate of 100% can be achieved only when all three EMs are employed (Table S2). After that, the identification potential of unknown protein samples was explored. As shown in Table S3, the sensor array has demonstrated a 100% identification level, indicating the excellent discrimination ability of the sensor array.

elements.content: Since the clinical research reported that the total protein content in CSF tends to show a dynamic change for PNM patients, the discriminating capability of the sensor array for different concentrations of proteins (50, 100, 300, and 400 μg·mL–1) has been evaluated. As expected, each protein has its specific responding pattern over a wide range of concentrations (Figures S7–S12), showing a perfect potential to be distinguished from each other. In addition, another challenge is to quantitatively determine the concentration of a given protein. HSA is taken as an example (d), the LDA plot for different concentrations of HSA (from 50 μg·mL–1 to 400 μg·mL–1) is clustered into five groups (e and S13), and a discriminant accuracy of 87.6% can be acquired based on the k-NN algorithm (f).
elements.clean_text: Since the clinical research reported that the total protein content in CSF tends to show a dynamic change for PNM patients, the discriminating capability of the sensor array for different concentrations of proteins (50, 100, 300, and 400 μg⋅mL-1) has been evaluated. As expected, each protein has its specific responding pattern over a wide range of concentrations (Figures S7-S12), showing a perfect potential to be distinguished from each other. In addition, another challenge is to quantitatively determine the concentration of a given protein. HSA is taken as an example (d), the LDA plot for different concentrations of HSA (from 50 μg⋅mL-1 to 400 μg⋅mL-1) is clustered into five groups (e and S13), and a discriminant accuracy of 87.6% can be acquired based on the k-NN algorithm (f).

elements.content: Next, the artificial CSF containing different proportions of HSA and LDH are prepared to investigate the discriminating ability in more complex changing of CFS. h and S14 reveal that artificial CSF with different proportions of HSA and LDH (from 50 μg·mL–1 HSA/400 μg·mL–1 LDH to 400 μg·mL–1 HSA/50 μg·mL–1 LDH) can be discriminated after the response patterns are analyzed by LDA. The discrimination confidence is 81.3% based on the k-NN algorithm (i).
elements.clean_text: Next, the artificial CSF containing different proportions of HSA and LDH are prepared to investigate the discriminating ability in more complex changing of CFS. h and S14 reveal that artificial CSF with different proportions of HSA and LDH (from 50 μg⋅mL-1 HSA/400 μg⋅mL-1 LDH to 400 μg⋅mL-1 HSA/50 μg⋅mL-1 LDH) can be discriminated after the response patterns are analyzed by LDA. The discrimination confidence is 81.3% based on the k-NN algorithm (i).

elements.content: The CSF leukocyte count is clinically regarded as a significant indicator of PNM. Therefore, RAW264.7, BV-2, and Thp-1 are chosen to test the discrimination and determination capability of the sensor array. The three EMs are reacted with six groups of cells, including three groups of individual cells and three groups of mixed cells (a and S15–S17). After being analyzed by LDA, the individual cells and mixed cells can be clearly discriminated with no overlap (b,c).
elements.clean_text:
Identification and Determination of CSF Cells

The CSF leukocyte count is clinically regarded as a significant indicator of PNM. Therefore, RAW264.7, BV-2, and Thp-1 are chosen to test the discrimination and determination capability of the sensor array. The three EMs are reacted with six groups of cells, including three groups of individual cells and three groups of mixed cells (a and S15-S17). After being analyzed by LDA, the individual cells and mixed cells can be clearly discriminated with no overlap (b,c).

elements.content: (a) Photoluminescence response (I 0 – I) patterns of the sensor array against various cells. LDA plots for the sensor array against various cell lines (b), the mixtures of different cells (c), and artificial cerebrospinal fluids containing different counts of RAW264.7 cells (d). (e) Relationship between factor 1 and the count of RAW264.7 cells. (f) Confusion matrix of the discrimination of artificial cerebrospinal fluids containing various cell lines at different counts based on the data of the entire sensor array.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Photoluminescence response (I 0 - I) patterns of the sensor array against various cells. LDA plots for the sensor array against various cell lines (b), the mixtures of different cells (c), and artificial cerebrospinal fluids containing different counts of RAW264.7 cells (d). (e) Relationship between factor 1 and the count of RAW264.7 cells. (f) Confusion matrix of the discrimination of artificial cerebrospinal fluids containing various cell lines at different counts based on the data of the entire sensor array.

elements.content: Fluorescence imaging is conducted to study whether the three EMs can be taken up by cells. It can be seen from Figure S18a that EMs hardly entered the inside of the cells as the reaction time was only 0.5 h. Therefore, the optical change of the three EMs mainly resulted from the molecules and proteins on the surface of cells. Then, the lifetime of the three EMs after reacting with BV-2, RAW264.7, and Thp-1 cells is measured. As shown in Figure S18b,d, the lifetime of EM3 was prolonged by adding BV-2 cells and shortened by adding RAW264.7 cells. This corresponded with the luminescence change by adding BV-2 and RAW264.7 cells, respectively.
elements.clean_text: Fluorescence imaging is conducted to study whether the three EMs can be taken up by cells. It can be seen from Figure S18a that EMs hardly entered the inside of the cells as the reaction time was only 0.5 h. Therefore, the optical change of the three EMs mainly resulted from the molecules and proteins on the surface of cells. Then, the lifetime of the three EMs after reacting with BV-2, RAW264.7, and Thp-1 cells is measured. As shown in Figure S18b,d, the lifetime of EM3 was prolonged by adding BV-2 cells and shortened by adding RAW264.7 cells. This corresponded with the luminescence change by adding BV-2 and RAW264.7 cells, respectively.

elements.content: The artificial cerebrospinal fluids containing different concentrations of RAW264.7 from 1000 to 10000 cells·mL–1 are introduced to three EMs to validate the quantitative ability of the sensor array (Figures S15–S17). The data are preliminarily analyzed by LDA; each group can be clustered with the most significant two factors (factor 1 = 95.4% and factor 2 = 4.0%) (d); factor 1 is linearly dependent on the concentration of RAW264.7 (e). Furthermore, the k-NN algorithm is used to assess the determination of cell counts of the sensor array, and a discriminant accuracy of 83.4% can be obtained (f).
elements.clean_text: The artificial cerebrospinal fluids containing different concentrations of RAW264.7 from 1000 to 10000 cells⋅mL-1 are introduced to three EMs to validate the quantitative ability of the sensor array (Figures S15-S17). The data are preliminarily analyzed by LDA; each group can be clustered with the most significant two factors (factor 1 = 95.4% and factor 2 = 4.0%) (d); factor 1 is linearly dependent on the concentration of RAW264.7 (e). Furthermore, the k-NN algorithm is used to assess the determination of cell counts of the sensor array, and a discriminant accuracy of 83.4% can be obtained (f).

elements.content: Based on the above experimental results, the sensor array performs excellently in distinguishing the content change of molecules, proteins, and cells in CSF. Forty-five CSF samples from neurosurgical patients are preliminarily classified into three types (normal, mild, and severe) based on their leukocyte count. The CSF is reacted with the sensor array, and the three types are diagnosed by evaluating the minimal Mahalanobis squared distance between the unknown samples and each cluster established by the training set in LDA (Tables S4 and S5). The results show that three types of unknown samples can be classified with an accuracy of 86.7% compared with the results of preliminary classification (a). What is more, misclassification is more common in mild and severe meningitis than in the normal group, implying its powerful disease diagnosis and discrimination ability. The classification accuracy given by the k-NN algorithm is 88.1% (b). Moreover, the previous data including molecules, proteins, cells, and CSF are further processed by the ANN algorithm. The confusion matrices and corresponding loss functions in Figure S19 also indicate the good validation performance of the sensor array.
elements.clean_text:
Diagnosis of PNM

Based on the above experimental results, the sensor array performs excellently in distinguishing the content change of molecules, proteins, and cells in CSF. Forty-five CSF samples from neurosurgical patients are preliminarily classified into three types (normal, mild, and severe) based on their leukocyte count. The CSF is reacted with the sensor array, and the three types are diagnosed by evaluating the minimal Mahalanobis squared distance between the unknown samples and each cluster established by the training set in LDA (Tables S4 and S5). The results show that three types of unknown samples can be classified with an accuracy of 86.7% compared with the results of preliminary classification (a). What is more, misclassification is more common in mild and severe meningitis than in the normal group, implying its powerful disease diagnosis and discrimination ability. The classification accuracy given by the k-NN algorithm is 88.1% (b). Moreover, the previous data including molecules, proteins, cells, and CSF are further processed by the ANN algorithm. The confusion matrices and corresponding loss functions in Figure S19 also indicate the good validation performance of the sensor array.

elements.content: (a) Distribution of points representing 45 individuals in the canonical score plot based on the training dataset (normal, mild, and severe). (b) Confusion matrix of the discrimination of various cerebrospinal fluid samples based on the data of the entire sensor array (1: normal; 2: mild; 3: severe). (c) Box-plot of factor 1 for two groups (meningitis and normal individuals). (d) ROC analysis of the two-group diagnostic study (normal vs mild, normal vs severe, and mild vs severe).
elements.clean_text: 5  (a) Distribution of points representing 45 individuals in the canonical score plot based on the training dataset (normal, mild, and severe). (b) Confusion matrix of the discrimination of various cerebrospinal fluid samples based on the data of the entire sensor array (1: normal; 2: mild; 3: severe). (c) Box-plot of factor 1 for two groups (meningitis and normal individuals). (d) ROC analysis of the two-group diagnostic study (normal vs mild, normal vs severe, and mild vs severe).

elements.content: To explore its specificity and sensitivity, the LDA dataset is transferred into a histogram of statistics to distinguish the meningitis group and the normal group; Figure S20a illustrates that the distribution curve is partially crossed. And there is a significant difference between scores of factor 1 in meningitis and normal individuals (c). Then, a more detailed analysis of the sensitivity and specificity of the sensor array is conducted through the receiver operator characteristic (ROC). The area under the curve (AUC) is calculated as 0.949, indicating the reliability of the sensor array in the diagnosis of bacterial meningitis (Figure S20b). In addition, under the premise of ensuring sensitivity and specificity, we obtain 93% sensitivity and 93% specificity according to the Youden index. Finally, we compare the diagnostic ability of the sensor array for normal and mild groups, normal and severe groups, and mild and severe groups by ROC. As shown in d, all three groups have a relatively high area under the curve (AUC > 0.87), which further proves that the sensor array is relatively reliable in the diagnosis of PNM.
elements.clean_text: To explore its specificity and sensitivity, the LDA dataset is transferred into a histogram of statistics to distinguish the meningitis group and the normal group; Figure S20a illustrates that the distribution curve is partially crossed. And there is a significant difference between scores of factor 1 in meningitis and normal individuals (c). Then, a more detailed analysis of the sensitivity and specificity of the sensor array is conducted through the receiver operator characteristic (ROC). The area under the curve (AUC) is calculated as 0.949, indicating the reliability of the sensor array in the diagnosis of bacterial meningitis (Figure S20b). In addition, under the premise of ensuring sensitivity and specificity, we obtain 93% sensitivity and 93% specificity according to the Youden index. Finally, we compare the diagnostic ability of the sensor array for normal and mild groups, normal and severe groups, and mild and severe groups by ROC. As shown in d, all three groups have a relatively high area under the curve (AUC > 0.87), which further proves that the sensor array is relatively reliable in the diagnosis of PNM.

elements.content: Besides, the CSF samples from the same patient were collected before and after the treatment, and the experiment was carried out in the same way as before. As shown in Figure S21, there is a significant difference between scores of factor 1 before and after the treatments.
elements.clean_text: Besides, the CSF samples from the same patient were collected before and after the treatment, and the experiment was carried out in the same way as before. As shown in Figure S21, there is a significant difference between scores of factor 1 before and after the treatments.

elements.content: In summary, we have successfully conducted a machine-learning-aided sensor array including three Eu3+-doped MOFs with different sizes, morphologies, and surface charges. The discrimination capability of the sensor array for different concentrations of molecules, proteins, and cells is verified. On this basis, the sensor array exhibits a powerful PNM diagnosis ability for unknown CSF samples from post-neurosurgical patients. This strategy of comprehensive CSF analysis may provide more accurate evidence for the diagnosis and prognosis of PNM; it can also be referenced for the diagnosis of other brain diseases based on CSF analysis.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we have successfully conducted a machine-learning-aided sensor array including three Eu3+-doped MOFs with different sizes, morphologies, and surface charges. The discrimination capability of the sensor array for different concentrations of molecules, proteins, and cells is verified. On this basis, the sensor array exhibits a powerful PNM diagnosis ability for unknown CSF samples from post-neurosurgical patients. This strategy of comprehensive CSF analysis may provide more accurate evidence for the diagnosis and prognosis of PNM; it can also be referenced for the diagnosis of other brain diseases based on CSF analysis.

cln_elements.content:
The sensing array is composed of three Eu3+-doped MOFs; they are Eu3+/UIO-66, Eu3+/HKUST-1, and Eu3+/MIL-53, denoted as EM1, EM2, and EM3. As shown in SEM images in , both EM1 and EM3 present a spherical structure, and the average sizes are 40 ± 5.62 and 200 ± 46 nm, respectively. EM2 shows an octahedral structure with an average size of 500 ± 50 nm. The PXRD patterns of the three EMs are consistent with their standard PXRD patterns, indicating that the doping of Eu3+ does not influence the crystal structure of MOFs (d–f). The FT-IR spectra correspond with their organic ligands (g) for EM1; the stretching vibrations of νas (−COO−) and νs (−COO−) at 1581 and 1396 cm–1 belong to the characteristic bands of the carboxylate group in ligands, and the peak of the benzene ring is at 1506 cm–1. As for EM2, the absorption band at 1630 cm–1 is attributed to the stretching vibration of −COOH groups; the peak at 1450 cm–1 is assigned to the stretching vibration of the −CC bond. For EM3, the peak at 600 cm–1 should correspond to Al–O stretching vibrations. Furthermore, the three Eu3+-doped MOFs reveal the main emission wavelength of Eu3+ (616 nm) upon excitation at 300 nm due to the sensitization of the organic ligand to Eu3+ (5D0–7F2), implying the successful introduction of Eu3+ (h). The ζ potentials of the three EMs are −24.5, −14.3, and −4.75 mV, respectively (i).

Since the clinical research reported that the total protein content in CSF tends to show a dynamic change for PNM patients, the discriminating capability of the sensor array for different concentrations of proteins (50, 100, 300, and 400 μg·mL–1) has been evaluated. As expected, each protein has its specific responding pattern over a wide range of concentrations (Figures S7–S12), showing a perfect potential to be distinguished from each other. In addition, another challenge is to quantitatively determine the concentration of a given protein. HSA is taken as an example (d), the LDA plot for different concentrations of HSA (from 50 μg·mL–1 to 400 μg·mL–1) is clustered into five groups (e and S13), and a discriminant accuracy of 87.6% can be acquired based on the k-NN algorithm (f).

To explore its specificity and sensitivity, the LDA dataset is transferred into a histogram of statistics to distinguish the meningitis group and the normal group; Figure S20a illustrates that the distribution curve is partially crossed. And there is a significant difference between scores of factor 1 in meningitis and normal individuals (c). Then, a more detailed analysis of the sensitivity and specificity of the sensor array is conducted through the receiver operator characteristic (ROC). The area under the curve (AUC) is calculated as 0.949, indicating the reliability of the sensor array in the diagnosis of bacterial meningitis (Figure S20b). In addition, under the premise of ensuring sensitivity and specificity, we obtain 93% sensitivity and 93% specificity according to the Youden index. Finally, we compare the diagnostic ability of the sensor array for normal and mild groups, normal and severe groups, and mild and severe groups by ROC. As shown in d, all three groups have a relatively high area under the curve (AUC > 0.87), which further proves that the sensor array is relatively reliable in the diagnosis of PNM.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Characterization of EM1, EM2, and EM3

The sensing array is composed of three Eu3+-doped MOFs; they are Eu3+/UIO-66, Eu3+/HKUST-1, and Eu3+/MIL-53, denoted as EM1, EM2, and EM3. As shown in SEM images in , both EM1 and EM3 present a spherical structure, and the average sizes are 40 ± 5.62 and 200 ± 46 nm, respectively. EM2 shows an octahedral structure with an average size of 500 ± 50 nm. The PXRD patterns of the three EMs are consistent with their standard PXRD patterns, indicating that the doping of Eu3+ does not influence the crystal structure of MOFs (d-f). The FT-IR spectra correspond with their organic ligands (g) for EM1; the stretching vibrations of νas (-COO-) and νs (-COO-) at 1581 and 1396 cm-1 belong to the characteristic bands of the carboxylate group in ligands, and the peak of the benzene ring is at 1506 cm-1. As for EM2, the absorption band at 1630 cm-1 is attributed to the stretching vibration of -COOH groups; the peak at 1450 cm-1 is assigned to the stretching vibration of the -CC bond. For EM3, the peak at 600 cm-1 should correspond to Al-O stretching vibrations. Furthermore, the three Eu3+-doped MOFs reveal the main emission wavelength of Eu3+ (616 nm) upon excitation at 300 nm due to the sensitization of the organic ligand to Eu3+ (5D0-7F2), implying the successful introduction of Eu3+ (h). The ζ potentials of the three EMs are -24.5, -14.3, and -4.75 mV, respectively (i).

Since the clinical research reported that the total protein content in CSF tends to show a dynamic change for PNM patients, the discriminating capability of the sensor array for different concentrations of proteins (50, 100, 300, and 400 μg⋅mL-1) has been evaluated. As expected, each protein has its specific responding pattern over a wide range of concentrations (Figures S7-S12), showing a perfect potential to be distinguished from each other. In addition, another challenge is to quantitatively determine the concentration of a given protein. HSA is taken as an example (d), the LDA plot for different concentrations of HSA (from 50 μg⋅mL-1 to 400 μg⋅mL-1) is clustered into five groups (e and S13), and a discriminant accuracy of 87.6% can be acquired based on the k-NN algorithm (f).

To explore its specificity and sensitivity, the LDA dataset is transferred into a histogram of statistics to distinguish the meningitis group and the normal group; Figure S20a illustrates that the distribution curve is partially crossed. And there is a significant difference between scores of factor 1 in meningitis and normal individuals (c). Then, a more detailed analysis of the sensitivity and specificity of the sensor array is conducted through the receiver operator characteristic (ROC). The area under the curve (AUC) is calculated as 0.949, indicating the reliability of the sensor array in the diagnosis of bacterial meningitis (Figure S20b). In addition, under the premise of ensuring sensitivity and specificity, we obtain 93% sensitivity and 93% specificity according to the Youden index. Finally, we compare the diagnostic ability of the sensor array for normal and mild groups, normal and severe groups, and mild and severe groups by ROC. As shown in d, all three groups have a relatively high area under the curve (AUC > 0.87), which further proves that the sensor array is relatively reliable in the diagnosis of PNM.

(f) Confusion matrix of the discrimination of artificial cerebrospinal fluids containing various cell lines at different counts based on the data of the entire sensor array.

cln_elements.content: (a) Distribution of points representing 45 individuals in the canonical score plot based on the training dataset (normal, mild, and severe). (b) Confusion matrix of the discrimination of various cerebrospinal fluid samples based on the data of the entire sensor array (1: normal; 2: mild; 3: severe). (c) Box-plot of factor 1 for two groups (meningitis and normal individuals). (d) ROC analysis of the two-group diagnostic study (normal vs mild, normal vs severe, and mild vs severe).
cln_elements.clean_text: 5  (a) Distribution of points representing 45 individuals in the canonical score plot based on the training dataset (normal, mild, and severe). (b) Confusion matrix of the discrimination of various cerebrospinal fluid samples based on the data of the entire sensor array (1: normal; 2: mild; 3: severe). (c) Box-plot of factor 1 for two groups (meningitis and normal individuals). (d) ROC analysis of the two-group diagnostic study (normal vs mild, normal vs severe, and mild vs severe).

metadata.title:
Intelligent
Clinical Lab for the Diagnosis of Post-Neurosurgical
Meningitis Based on Machine-Learning-Aided Cerebrospinal Fluid Analysis
